title: Wilko strikes suspended after two days of 'gruelling' talks
text:

Wilko workers have called off strikes at two major distribution centres after a two-day debate over working hours.

Union GMB said industrial action has been suspended after 48 hours of 'gruelling' talks.

The strikes on October 11 and 14 have now been called off after last ditch talks produced an improved offer.

GMB will now ballot members to see if they accept the new offer.

The ballot will run from Friday October 11 to Thursday October 17.

"After two days of intense talks we have negotiated an improved offer which we will put to members.

"The planned industrial action on October 11and 14 will now be put on hold until we ballot members on the new offer."

(Image: Google Street View)

A Wilko statement told Mirror Money that enabling workers with sufficient time off to care for their families is "top priority".

“Through working collaboratively with the GMB we have found a way forward which has led to the suspension of strike action," the retailer said.

“The GMB will now put this improved offer to its members.

“Throughout the talks, as a family business, finding a workable way to land 7 day operations and guarantee more time off for our team members to spend with their families has been our top priority, our new offer will deliver this.

“It’s no secret retail is tough and we believe the best way to resolve our differences is by listening, talking and working things through together.

"We’re looking forward to working closely with the GMB to implement 7 day operations that meet our customers’ shopping needs, is right for team members and our business.”
description: The strikes on October 11 and 14 have now been called off after last ditch talks produced an improved offer
